For the last 12 years, Fox Lane High School Bridges to Community groups have traveled to Nicaragua and the Dominican Republic to help build houses, latrines and classrooms. Though they can't return this year due to the pandemic, they still want to help.

Students are trying to raise $1,500 to provide water and hand-washing stations for a school in Nicaragua. During the past three trips there, FLHS students stayed at the Miguel Larreynaga school in the community of Las Conchitas in Masaya while building houses in the local community. Access to water is very difficult for the community as one well is shared by several communities with over 6,000 people. The school receives water service every other day for a few hours. A 5,000-litre water tank and six hand-washing stations will enable children to attend school safely. For more information and to donate, click through!

Our community continues to impress us!

Trying to find a way to both engage student-athletes and do something positive for the community, Director of Health, PE & Athletics Adam Lodewick and a few of his coaches came up with the #FoxesUp4Heroes challenge: using social media, coaches and athletes are challenging each other to do creative at-home workouts and, if they choose, follow-up by making a donation to a GoFundMe page they set up to benefit Northern Westchester Hospital.

What started as a few kids and coaches at Fox Lane has quickly spread to rival districts (which sparked a new hashtag: #RivalsUnite4Heroes).

The initial $10,000 goal that was set five days ago has been increased to $15,000 as the challenge has already raised $8,492.

For more information: https://tinyurl.com/vefgfcn
To donate: https://www.gofundme.com/f/foxesup4heroes

It's A Seuss-A-Bration!
Bedford Hills Elementary spent the week celebrating the legacy of Dr. Seuss.

Dr. Seuss Week began with our highly anticipated Community Readers Event. Members of our school and local community joined us to read to our classes. Every class in the school was visited by a community member to read a Dr. Seuss book.
The celebration continued throughout the week with festive days including red & white day, wear a shirt you can read, pajama day, colors day and hat day!
Thursday night we held our annual Seuss-A-Bration; an annual event that so many look forward to.Friday we started our day with the Bedford Hills Reading Train; all students, teachers and staff lined the halls and spent time reading independently. Our Seuss celebrations culminated with buddy reading and a school-wide assembly. The assembly included a performance of What Pet Should I Get? starring our fifth grade students!

We had fun, but now it‚Äôs done,
We can‚Äôt wait see, what next year will be!

post_text: BVES 5th grade classes traveled to the moon and back during their recent field trip to the Challenger Learning Center. For their missions, students worked collaboratively in order to successfully blast off, place their shuttle into orbit, land a probe on the moon's surface, and return safely to Earth. This captivating simulation drew upon skills in science, mathematics, literacy, and communication, while focusing on problem-solving and research abilities. Thank you to BVESA and Bedford Chowder and Marching Club for making this field trip possible.
